column2: PERSONAL HEALTH
column6: This course examines the leading causes of death and disability in the United States with an emphasis on the application of knowledge and skills to reduce risk and enhance the quality of life.

column2: COMMUNITY HEALTH EDUCATION
column6: Identification of community health problems and measures for control. Emphasizes principles, objectives and methods of community health education.

column2: WINNING COMBINATION: HEALTH AND ATHLETES
column6: An exploration of strategies for promoting healthy lifestyles for athletes. The course is reserved for varsity athletes.

column2: MEDICAL TERMINOLOGY
column6: Identification of the meaning of various roots and terms and combining forms that are components of medical words, including anatomical physiological and pathological therapeutic terminology and implications for health literacy.

column2: HEALTH EDUCATION FOR EARLY CHILDHOOD EDUCATORS
column6: Investigate current health issues relevant to children in preschool environments/primary grades, and identify educational strategies to increase student health knowledge, foster positive health attitudes and promote healthy behaviors.

column2: INTRODUCTION TO HEALTH EDUCATION
column6: This course introduces the student to the health education profession. Roles and responsibilities of health educators in a variety of occupational settings are described.

column2: HEALTH EDUCATION THEORIES
column6: Application of various attitude and behavior models to health and illness behavior in order to develop a framework for educational intervention.

column2: DRUG USE AND MISUSE
column6: Introduction to the study of drug/alcohol abuse. Basic pharmacology of drug actions is reviewed. Common myths misconceptions about drug alcohol use are examined. Current drug problems and related prevention treatment issues are analyzed.

column2: METHODS AND APPLICATIONS OF HEALTH EDUCATION
column6: Analysis observation, demonstration and experience in the teaching-learning process utilizing methods, materials and resources appropriate to the preparation of professional health educators. This course includes 50 field/clinical hours. Students are required to complete Bureau of Criminal Investigation and Identification (BCII) and Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) background checks and submit the results to authorized personnel at their assigned ¿school/agency¿ before the first day of the semester in which student teaching/ internship will take place.

column2: HUMAN SEXUALITY
column6: A study of the role and meaning of human sexuality throughout the life cycle for self and society.

column2: MARKETING IN HEALTH EDUCATION
column6: Examines the basic elements of marketing processes as they relate to promoting health in communities. Emphasis on application of marketing planning, concepts and practices for service providers involved with health education.

column2: CONSUMER HEALTH
column6: An overview of the health marketplace including health products, services, financing, promotional practices and consumer protection laws.

column2: PROGRAM PLANNING AND EVALUATION IN HEALTH EDUCATION
column6: Provides students with the knowledge and skills to assess health resources and needs, develop health programs to meet specific needs in particular populations and determine appropriate measures to evaluate the effectiveness of health programs.

column2: SMALL GROUP PROCESSES
column6: Group processes in human relationships, including techniques of democratic leadership and effective group membership. This course includes 25 field/clinical hours.

column2: EMERGENCY MEDICAL TRAINING
column6: Basic immediate care procedures for victims of acute illnesses and accidents. Course does not conform to EMT-B National Standard Curriculum as adopted by the Ohio Department of Public Safety, Division of EMS.

column2: VARIABLE TITLE WORKSHOP IN HEALTH EDUCATION AND PROMOTION
column4: vary depending on workshop. Prerequisite: HED 11590 and special approval.
column6: (Repeatable for credit) Discussion of major issues in health and safety education. Content emphasis and

column2: HEALTH COUNSELING
column6: Techniques of counseling applied to health education. Individual and group approaches relative to personal, family and societal health issues. This course includes 20 field/clinical hours.

column2: STUDENT TEACHING IN HEALTH EDUCATION
column4: Eligibility for admission to student teaching and admission to advanced study.
column6: Provides a twelve week student teaching experience. See student teaching section of catalog. Students are required to complete Bureau of Criminal Investigation and Identification (BCII) and Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) background checks and submit the results to authorized personnel at their assigned ¿school/agency¿ before the first day of the semester in which student teaching/ internship will take place.

column2: HEALTH AND LEARNING: STRATEGIES FOR STUDENTS AND TEACHERS
column6: Focus on health issues/education/environment policy and practice/community strategies to respond to threats confronting students utilizing a coordinated school/community strategy to promote health to improve academic outcomes. CPR and first aid certification required for completion of course.

column2: WOMEN'S HEALTH ISSUES
column6: Traditional and feminist analysis of women's health issues and the health educational responses to those issues.

column2: INTERNSHIP IN COMMUNITY HEALTH EDUCATION
column6: (Repeatable for credit)Participation for one academic semester in the health education activities of an approved agency, organization or industry.

column2: INDIVIDUAL INVESTIGATION IN HEALTH EDUCATION AND PROMOTION
column6: (Repeatable for credit) Independent reading and/or research directed by a HED faculty member.

column2: ADMINISTRATION OF SCHOOL HEALTH PROGRAMS
column6: Organizational design and administration of a comprehensive school health program including health services, instruction and environment. This course includes 25 field/clinical hours. CPR and first aid certification required for completion of course.

column2: SEXUALITY EDUCATION PROGRAMS
column6: This course prepares the student to develop, implement and evaluate sexuality education programs in school and community settings.

column2: DRUG ABUSE AND VIOLENCE EDUCATION PROGRAMS
column6: Drug abuse and violence prevention from theoretical, philosophical, empirical and practical perspectives. Application of theories to plan, implement, and evaluate drug and violence education programs.

column2: STRESS: RECOGNITION AND MANAGEMENT
column6: An examination of stress, its role as a predisposing factor for various illnesses and diseases, types of stressors, the body's reaction to stress, and techniques for recognizing, preventing and reducing stress.

column2: ADVANCED HUMAN SEXUALITY
column6: Selected aspects of human sexuality; history, cross-cultural perspectives, medical/surgical conditions and sex therapy and counseling.

column2: HEALTH RELATED ASPECTS OF AGING
column6: Theories of biological aging and identification of major health hazards, age-related diseases and age changes, their prevention and control. The health care delivery system for the elderly.

column2: AIDS: ISSUES, EDUCATION AND PREVENTION
column6: This course provides an extensive overview of the human immunodeficiency virus epidemic as it has developed and exists today. A particular emphasis will be given to aids education and prevention issues and strategies.

column2: FIELD EXPERIENCE IN HEALTH EDUCATION AND PROMOTION
column6: (Repeatable for credit)Observation and participation in educational and promotional activities of a public health agency, school or health care facility. Joint university agency supervision.

column2: INQUIRY SEMINAR INTO PROFESSIONAL PRACTICE
column6: Interdisciplinary inquiry into teaching as a professional practice in health education; emphasis on teacher as disciplined investigator. Utilization of teaching and learning technology.

column2: VARIABLE TITLE WORKSHOP IN HEALTH EDUCATION AND PROMOTION
column4: vary depending on workshop. Prerequisite: Graduate standing.
column6: (Repeatable for credit) Discussion of major issues in health and safety education. Content emphasis and

column2: HEALTH COUNSELING
column6: Techniques of counseling applied to health education. Individual and group approaches relative to personal family and societal health issues. The course includes 20 field clinical hours.

column2: HEALTH AND LEARNING: STRATEGIES FOR STUDENTS AND TEACHERS
column6: Focus on health issues/education/environment policy and practice/community strategies to respond to threats confronting students, utilizing a coordinated school community strategy to promote health and improve academic outcomes. CPR first aid certification required for completion of course.

column2: WOMEN'S HEALTH ISSUES
column6: Traditional and feminist analysis of women's health issues and the health educational responses to those issues.

column2: INDIVIDUAL INVESTIGATION IN HEALTH EDUCATION AND PROMOTION
column6: (Repeatable for credit)Independent reading and/or research directed by a graduate faculty member. Students are required to complete Bureau of Criminal Investigation and Identification (BCII) and Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) background checks and submit the results to authorized personnel at their assigned ¿school/agency¿ before the first day of the semester in which student teaching/ internship will take place.

column2: ADMINISTRATION OF SCHOOL HEALTH PROGRAMS
column6: Organizational design and administration of a comprehensive school health program including health services, instruction and environment. This course includes 25 field/clinical hours. CPR and first aid certification required for completion of course.

column2: SEXUALITY EDUCATION PROGRAMS
column6: This course prepares the student to develop, implement and evaluate sexuality education programs in school and community settings.

column2: DRUG ABUSE AND VIOLENCE EDUCATION PROGRAMS
column6: Drug abuse and violence prevention from theoretical, philosophical, empirical, and practical perspectives. Application of theories to plan, implement, and evaluate drug and violence education programs.

column2: ADVANCED HUMAN SEXUALITY
column6: Selected aspects of human sexuality: history, cross-cultural perspectives, medical/surgical therapy and counseling.

column2: HEALTH RELATED ASPECTS OF AGING
column6: Theories of biological aging and identification of major health hazards, age-related diseases and age changes, their prevention and control. The health care delivery system for the elderly.

column2: AIDS: ISSUES, EDUCATION AND PREVENTION
column6: This course provides an extensive overview of the human immunodeficiency virus epidemic as it has developed and exists today. A particular emphasis will be given to AIDS education and prevention issues and strategies.

column2: FIELD EXPERIENCE IN HEALTH EDUCATION AND PROMOTION
column6: (Repeatable for credit) Observation and participation in educational and promotional activities of a public health agency, school, or health care facility joint university-agency supervision. Students are required to complete Bureau of Criminal Investigation and Identification (BCII) and Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) background checks and submit the results to authorized personnel at their assigned school/agency before the first day of the semester in which student teaching/ internship will take place.

column2: THESIS I
column6: Thesis students must register for a total of 6 hours, 2 to 6 hours in a single semester distributed over several semesters if desired.

column2: THESIS II
column6: Thesis students must continue registration each semester until all degree Requirements are met.

column2: RESOURCES AND TRAINING IN HEALTH EDUCATION AND PROMOTION
column6: Focuses on locating, evaluating, and creating health education and promotion resources as well as gaining skills to enable the planning, facilitation, and evaluation of health promotion trainings. Students complete CITI training as a course competency.

column2: INTRODUCTION TO RESEARCH AND DATA ANALYSIS IN HEALTH EDUCATION AND PROMOTION
column6: Introduction of research methods in the field of health education and health promotion. Includes basic knowledge and skills in research design and concepts of descriptive and inferential statistics.

column2: HEALTH BEHAVIOR
column4: HED 64010 and HED 64061 and graduate standing.
column6: Analysis of a broad range of theoretical and empirical models of health and illness behavior.

column2: BIOBEHAVIORAL ASPECTS OF DISEASE PREVENTION IN HEALTH EDUCATION AND PROMOTION
column6: The etiology and pathogenesis of major diseases are studied from a biopsychosocial perspective with an emphasis on implications for disease prevention, health promotion and behavioral intervention.

column2: NEEDS ASSESSMENT AND PROGRAM PLANNING IN HEALTH PROMOTION
column4: HED 64010 and HED 64061 and HED 64072 and HED 64050 and HED 64063 and HED 64059 and graduate standing.
column6: Students will assess individual and community needs for health promotion programs based on multiple sources of health data. Students will develop a rational plan to meet identified needs.

column2: EVALUATION OF HEALTH PROMOTION PROGRAMS
column4: HED 64010 and HED 64050 and HED 64055 and HED 64061 and HED 64063 and HED 64072 and graduate standing.
column6: Reviews basic principles and types of evaluations. Students will develop an evaluation plan to determine effectiveness of program developed in HED 6/74055.

column2: DEVELOPMENTAL APPROACH TO CONTENT AND RESOURCES IN HEALTH EDUCATION
column6: Focus on examination of six CDC problem priority areas through the lens of developmentally appropriate practice parameters for children and youth.

column2: COMMUNICATION AND MARKETING IN HEALTH EDUCATION AND PROMOTION
column4: HED 64010 and HED 64050 and HED 64061 and HED 64072 and graduate standing.
column6: Introduction to the theory and practice of planning, implementing, and evaluating marketing and communication programs in health promotion.

column2: GRANT WRITING FOR HEALTH EDUCATION AND PROMOTION
column6: Focuses on the development of basic grant writing skills for health educators, including the search for funding sources and proposal development.

column2: FOUNDATIONS OF HEALTH EDUCATION AND PROMOTION
column6: Historical, sociological and philosophical factors that have influenced definitions and the practice of health education and promotion are studied. Professional associations/leadership, government initiatives, standards of practice and accreditations are examined.

column2: ADMINISTRATION OF HEALTH PROMOTION PROGRAMS
column4: HED 64010 and HED 64061 and graduate standing.
column6: Basic concepts in the administration of health education/promotion programs. Coordination of program services, consultative relationships, management of human and fiscal resources and organizational leadership are addressed.

column2: STRATEGIES IN HEALTH EDUCATION AND PROMOTION
column6: Health education and promotion methods, techniques and strategies are presented for a variety of audiences, learning environments and intervention levels.

column2: WORKSITE HEALTH PROMOTION
column6: Program planning and evaluation of health promotion programs in business and industry with an emphasis on the role of health educators.

column2: ADVOCACY AND POLICY ISSUES IN HEALTH EDUCATION AND PROMOTION
column6: Emphasizes the advocacy role of health educators. Includes use of research results to develop, analyze and influence health policy.

column2: READINGS IN HEALTH EDUCATION AND PROMOTION
column4: Graduate standing and Health Education (HED) or Public Health (PH) major.
column6: Independent study of approved topics in health and safety education related to the student's special interests. Adviser's permission required to repeat registration one time.

column2: COLLEGE TEACHING OF HEALTH EDUCATION AND PROMOTION
column6: (Repeatable for credit) Guided experiences in teaching selected undergraduate courses.

column2: PROJECT IN HEALTH EDUCATION AND PROMOTION
column6: (Repeatable for credit) Research or individual investigation for master's level graduate students.

column2: INDIVIDUAL INVESTIGATION IN HEALTH EDUCATION AND PROMOTION
column6: (Repeatable for credit) Independent reading and/or research directed by a graduate faculty member. Students are required to complete Bureau of Criminal Investigation and Identification (BCII) and Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) background checks and submit the results to authorized personnel at their assigned ¿school/agency¿ before the first day of the semester in which student teaching/ internship will take place.

column2: DISSERTATION I
column6: (Repeatable for credit) Registration for two semesters required, first semester dissertation work begins and continues until completion of 30 hours.

column2: PRACTICUM IN HEALTH EDUCATION AND PROMOTION 3.000
DISSERTATION II
column6: (Repeatable for credit) Continuing registration required of doctoral students who have completed the initial 30 hours of dissertation and continuing until degree Requirements are met.

column2: RESIDENCY SEMINAR: SYNTHESIS OF LITERATURE IN HEALTH EDUCATION AND PROMOTION
column4: doctoral standing and special approval of instructor.
column6: Exploration of philosophical, theoretical and empirical issues in health education and promotion. Students synthesize courses, research and practice in preparation for comprehensive examinations.

column2: SEMINAR: PROFESSIONAL DEVELOPMENT IN HEALTH EDUCATION AND PROMOTION
column6: Focuses on the process, practice and documentation of professional development in health education and promotion in the areas of instruction, program development, research and evaluation.

column2: RESIDENCY SEMINAR: RESEARCH PROPOSAL, DEVELOPMENT AND PRESENTATION
column4: Doctoral standing and special approval of instructor.
column6: Review of the role of research and scholarly pursuits in the professorate, the professional health education literature, and in the development and dissemination of a range of scholarly products. Identification of requisite elements of a dissertation in health education and promotion. Refinement of a professional vita, updating of doctoral program prospectus, specification of dissertation topic, identification of potential dissertation committee members, development and presentation of draft dissertation proposal.

column2: HEALTH EDUCATION PRACTICE
column6: Investigation of various health education settings including analysis of agency programming efforts and comparison to evidence-based practice. Application of community assessment, socioecological model, and community-based participatory research principles. Analysis of how health education theory and research are implemented in various practice settings.

column2: RESEARCH DISSEMINATION AND TECHNICAL WRITING IN HEALTH EDUCATION AND PROMOTION
column6: Examination and practice of technical writing for research proposals, technical reports, and journal publications in health education and promotion. Other methods of disseminating research such as preparation and submission of conference presentation applications and writing as part of consultative relationships with community agencies is explored.

column2: ADVANCED PROGRAM EVALUATION IN HEALTH EDUCATION AND PROMOTION
column4: HED 64055 or HED 74055; and HED 64057 or HED 74057; and doctoral standing.
column6: A review of evaluation methods used in health education programs. Emphasis is placed on data collection procedures, linking program activities to outcomes, participant attrition and reporting of the results.

column2: APPLIED THEORY IN HEALTH EDUCATION RESEARCH AND PRACTICE
column6: Examination of theory/models/hypotheses applied to specific health behaviors. Emphasis on operationalization of theoretical constructs.

column2: RESOURCES AND TRAINING IN HEALTH EDUCATION AND PROMOTION
column6: Focuses on locating, evaluating and creating health education and promotion resources as well as gaining skills to enable the planning, facilitation and evaluation of health promotion trainings. Students complete CITI training as a course competency.

column2: INTRODUCTION TO RESEARCH AND DATA ANALYSIS IN HEALTH EDUCATION AND PROMOTION
column6: Introduction of research methods in the field of health education and health promotion. Includes basic knowledge and skills in research design and concepts of descriptive and inferential statistics.

column2: HEALTH BEHAVIOR
column4: HED 64010; and HED 64061 or 84061 and doctoral standing.
column6: Analysis of a broad range of theoretical and empirical models of health and illness behavior.

column2: BIOBEHAVIORAL ASPECTS OF DISEASE PREVENTION IN HEALTH EDUCATION AND PROMOTION
column6: The etiology and pathogenesis of major diseases are studied from a biopsychosocial perspective with an emphasis on implications for disease prevention, health promotion and behavioral intervention.

column2: NEEDS ASSESS AND PROG/PLAN
column4: HED 64010; and HED 64050 or 84050; and HED 64059 or 84059; and HED 64061 or 84061; and HED 64063 or 84063; and HED 64072; and doctoral standing.
column6: Students will assess individual and community needs for health promotion programs based on multiple sources of health data. Students will develop a rational plan to meet identified needs.

column4: HED 64010; and HED 64050 or 84050; and HED 64055 or 84055; and HED 64061 or 84061; and HED 64063 or 84063; and HED 64072; and doctoral standing.
column6: Reviews basic principles and types of evaluations. Students will develop an evaluation plan to determine effectiveness of program developed in HED 6/84055.

column6: Focus on examination of six CDC problem priority areas through the lens of developmentally appropriate practice parameters for children and youth.

column6: Introduction to the theory and practice of planning, implementing, and evaluating marketing and communication programs in health promotion.

column2: GRANT WRITING FOR HEALTH EDUCATION AND PROMOTION
column6: Focuses on the development of basic grant writing skills for health educators, including the search for funding sources and proposal development.

column6: Historical, sociological and philosophical factors that have influenced definitions and the practice of health education and promotion are studied. Professional associations/ leadership, government initiatives, standards of practice and accreditations are examined.

column4: HED 64010; and HED 64061 or 84061; and doctoral standing.
column6: Basic concepts in the administration of health education/promotion programs. Coordination of program services, consultative relationships management of human and fiscal resources and organizational leadership are addressed.

column2: STRATEGIES IN HEALTH EDUCATION AND PROMOTION
column6: Health education and promotion methods, techniques and strategies are presented for a variety of audiences, learning environments and intervention levels.

column2: HEALTH IN THE DEVELOPING NATIONS
column6: Overview of national development, review of problems process and strategy of health development.

column2: WORKSITE HEALTH PROMOTION
column6: Program planning and evaluation of health promotion programs in business and industry with an emphasis on the role of health educators.

column6: Emphasizes the advocacy role of health educators. Includes use of research results to develop analyze and influence health policy.

column6: Independent study of approved topics in health and safety education related to the student's special interests. Adviser's permission required to repeat registration one time.

column6: (Repeatable for credit)Guided experiences in teaching selected undergraduate courses.

column6: (Repeatable for credit) Research or individual investigation for doctoral level graduate students.
